If you need to search through an array and find a unique value in the dataset then you should consider using the .find() method, and here's why.

Examples

.find()

    let people = ['sally', 'tom', 'brent', 'james'];
    let personIWant = people.find((person) => {
        console.log(person)
        return person === 'brent';
    });

The find() method searches our array looking for the first instance of the item that matches our conditional, in this case we are telling JavaScript to search for 'brent'. If a match is found, that match will be returned and the loop will break.

.forEach()

    let people = ['sally', 'tom', 'brent', 'james'];

    let personIWant;
    people.forEach((person) => {
        console.log(person)
        if (person === 'brent') {
            personIWant = person;
        }
    });

Traditional For Loop

    let people = ['sally', 'tom', 'brent', 'james'];

    for (let i = 0; i < people.length; i++) {
        console.log(people[i])
        if (people[i] === 'brent') {
            personIWant = 'brent';
            break;
        }
    };

Thank you for taking the time to read my post today if you've made it this far! Happy coding! :)
